qas.question: Who can benefit from two-way communication forums?
What is a major barrier to videoconferencing between some communities?
What is one example of how students can benefit from videoconferencing?
What is one experience that students using videoconferencing can achieve?

plausible_answers.text: the opportunity to learn by participating in two-way communication forums

qas.question: What do geographically isolated areas provide to students?
Who can  be brought to small schools to help students learn?
What will persist when teachers and lecturers are brought together?

plausible_answers.text: visit other parts of the world to speak with their peers, and visit museums and educational facilities

qas.question: What can students do through geographically isolated locations
Who can learn from foreign language forums?

context: Videoconferencing provides <a1_0><b9_0>students<b9_0/><a1_0/> with <b5_0>the opportunity to learn by <a0_0>participating in two-way communication forums<b5_0/><a0_0/>. Furthermore, <b6_0>teachers and lecturers worldwide<b6_0/> can be brought to remote or otherwise isolated educational facilities. Students from diverse communities and backgrounds can come together to learn about one another, although <a2_0><b7_0>language<a2_0/> barriers<b7_0/> will continue to persist. Such students are able to explore, communicate, analyze and share information and ideas with one another. Through videoconferencing, students can <b8_0>visit other parts of the world to speak with their peers, and <a4_0>visit museums<a4_0/> and educational facilities<b8_0/>. Such <a3_0>virtual field trips<a3_0/> can provide enriched learning opportunities to students, especially those in geographically isolated locations, and to the economically disadvantaged. Small schools can use these technologies to pool resources and provide courses, such as in foreign languages, which could not otherwise be offered.
